free_text.Learning outcomes: To know the basics of Mathematica programming. To use Mathematica to model physical phenomena in materials science and to analyse experimental data. To know how to use of the standard Mathematica packages. To develop new packages for specific applications. To write scientific reports using Mathematica.[br/]
free_text.Content: -	Description of the Mathematica Front-end and Kernel.[br/]-	Solution of linear and non-linear equations.[br/]-	Plot of 2-D and 3-D functions.[br/]-	Data lists and their representation, reading data files.[br/]-	Differentiation, symbolic and numerical integration.[br/]-	Expressions, functions, lists, vectors, matrices and tensors.[br/]- Solving ordinary differential equations, Laplace and Fourier transforms.[br/]- Tensors. [br/]-	Using standard graphics libraries.[br/]-	Procedural programming.[br/]-	Functional programming.[br/]-	Rule based programming.[br/]-	Graphical programming.[br/]-	Writing packages.[br/]-	Writing notebooks and scientific reports.[br/][br/][br/][br/]
free_text.Prerequisite for: Laboratory works, courses, analysis of experimental results
free_text.Form of examination: Writing a notebook about an optional or proposed subject
